content.raw: should never fail :)
content.html: should never fail :)

content.raw: I see that the simulated IMU uses numerical differentiation. It would be preferable to use the robot's instantaneous joint velocities and accelerations to compute a matching instantaneous IMU linear acceleration. Numerical differentiation introduces noise and delay. Granted, these could be added later, but ground truth should also be available.
content.html: I see that the simulated IMU uses numerical differentiation. It would be preferable to use the robot's instantaneous joint velocities and accelerations to compute a matching instantaneous IMU linear acceleration. Numerical differentiation introduces noise and delay. Granted, these could be added later, but ground truth should also be available.

content.raw: Returns the imu linear acceleration.
content.html: Returns the imu linear acceleration.

content.raw:
There are helper functions in pull request #270 for getting the linear velocity of a specific point on a body, which appears to be what you're doing here.

Also, I think this is the wrong way to compute acceleration, since it doesn't account for the rotation of the parent frame. It may be simpler to differentiate the velocity in a global frame, and then rotate into the parent frame.

There should be comments here describing our math, as well as tests with rotating bodies to verify that it's working correctly. I'll take a crack at it.
content.html:
There are helper functions in pull request #270 for getting the linear velocity of a specific point on a body, which appears to be what you're doing here.

Also, I think this is the wrong way to compute acceleration, since it doesn't account for the rotation of the parent frame. It may be simpler to differentiate the velocity in a global frame, and then rotate into the parent frame.

There should be comments here describing our math, as well as tests with rotating bodies to verify that it's working correctly. I'll take a crack at it.
